trans-unit.source: Enabling remote JMX with no authentication or SSL

seg-source.mrk: Enabling remote JMX with no authentication or SSL

target.mrk: Enabling remote JMX with no authentication or SSL

trans-unit.source: The following simple example starts the Network Server on the command line with insecure remote JMX management and monitoring enabled, using an Oracle JDK 6 or later JVM.

seg-source.mrk: The following simple example starts the Network Server on the command line with insecure remote JMX management and monitoring enabled, using an Oracle JDK 6 or later JVM.

target.mrk: The following simple example starts the Network Server on the command line with insecure remote JMX management and monitoring enabled, using an Oracle JDK 6 or later JVM.

trans-unit.source: Password authentication over SSL is enabled by default, but here these security features are disabled, to keep the example simple.

seg-source.mrk: Password authentication over SSL is enabled by default, but here these security features are disabled, to keep the example simple.

target.mrk: Password authentication over SSL is enabled by default, but here these security features are disabled, to keep the example simple.

trans-unit.source: It is not recommended to disable authentication or SSL in production environments.

seg-source.mrk: It is not recommended to disable authentication or SSL in production environments.

target.mrk: It is not recommended to disable authentication or SSL in production environments.

trans-unit.source: When you start the Network Server from the command line, it automatically installs a security manager using a basic default security policy, unless you specify the <codeph>-noSecurityManager</codeph> option. You may need to customize this policy to make it suit your needs. See <xref href="radminjmxenablepolicy.dita#radminjmxenablepolicy"></xref> for details.

seg-source.mrk: When you start the Network Server from the command line, it automatically installs a security manager using a basic default security policy, unless you specify the <codeph>-noSecurityManager</codeph> option.
You may need to customize this policy to make it suit your needs.

target.mrk: When you start the Network Server from the command line, it automatically installs a security manager using a basic default security policy, unless you specify the <codeph>-noSecurityManager</codeph> option.
You may need to customize this policy to make it suit your needs.
